summary: Build a Shopify-like e-commerce platform with full Shopify-style UI/UX and functionality, enabling anyone to create and run an online store (multi-store/multi-seller).
architectural_notes: Platform goal: Shopify-like multi-store e-commerce with role-based access (seller/dropshipper) and storefront + checkout.
Avoid third-party/trademarked branding in UI text; use platform brand name 'Shanju' across landing/marketing surfaces.
Routing rule: if user is authenticated (already logged in), visiting / should redirect to the dashboard (landing page is only for unauthenticated users).
Seller dashboard redesign should follow the provided Shopify-style screenshot closely but must use 'Shanju' branding anywhere a Shopify name would appear; slight layout variation is acceptable.

Store creation/onboarding should be one-time per authenticated Internet Identity principal; if a supplier profile/store already exists for the logged-in user, the app should not prompt or force the Create Store flow again and should route the user directly to the Seller Dashboard.
known_issues: 'Start free trial' on the landing page does not actually onboard/authenticate users (no magic link/password/OTP is sent and users cannot reach the dashboard).
After completing free-trial login, returning users still see the landing page; requirement is to route authenticated users directly to the dashboard on repeat visits.
Seller Dashboard redesign is still not matching the provided Shopify-style screenshot/layout closely enough (user feedback: 'সেইম হয়নি' / 'not the same').
Three-dot (ellipsis) menu in the Seller Dashboard/top bar is not updated to match the provided screenshot; user requests all related options/settings be aligned to the screenshot.

Create Store flow/page is being shown repeatedly even after the user is logged in and has already created/linked a store; the store should remain associated with the same login and not require re-creation.
UI/layout elements become jumbled/overlap ('সব একসাতে এলোমেলো হয়ে যায়') and need spacing/alignment adjustments (likely responsive layout issue).
Three-dot (overflow) menu dropdown/options background should be white (improve menu readability/visual match to screenshot).

existing_features.title: Apply a cohesive, Shopify-like visual design system across the app (Home, Header, Footer, Products, Suppliers, Cart, Checkout, Payment Success/Failure) with consistent spacing, typography, and component styling; use English for all user-facing text.

Choose and enforce ONE distinct visual theme (colors, typography, layout) that is not blue/purple-dominant, and update Tailwind/theme tokens accordingly so the whole UI matches (including gradients currently used in HomePage/Header).

Add a self-serve “Create Store” (seller onboarding) flow so any authenticated user can open a store on the platform by creating/updating their supplier profile (store name, description, contact info).

Implement a seller dashboard that is accessible only to users who have a supplier profile (store created) and provides: store overview, list of their products, and actions to add/update/delete products.

Upgrade the storefront browsing experience to be Shopify-like: improve Products and Suppliers pages with better merchandising UI (filters/sorting remain), and add navigation from Suppliers to a supplier-specific product listing.
Add and use required static generated images under frontend/public/assets/generated, and update UI to use them consistently where appropriate (brand + hero + placeholders).

Add seller-facing product photo upload and management so a supplier can attach one or more images to a product, persist them on the backend, and display the primary product image across the storefront and cart.
Implement a product category system: maintain a category list, allow sellers to assign a category to products, and allow shoppers to browse/filter products by category.

Add a dedicated Store View page that displays a supplier’s store profile (name, description, contact info when available) and lists only that supplier’s products, with navigation entry points from the Suppliers page and the seller dashboard.

Make inventory (stock quantity) clearly manageable and visible: ensure sellers can edit stock from the product form and optionally adjust stock quickly from the seller product list, and ensure storefront pages consistently show stock and prevent adding out-of-stock items to cart.

Redesign the public store landing page (frontend/src/pages/StoreViewPage.tsx) to match the Shopify store landing page screenshot provided by the user, recreating the same overall layout, spacing, section structure, and visual hierarchy while keeping all user-facing text in English.

Ensure the redesigned store landing page continues to use the existing StoreViewPage data sources (supplier profile and supplier products) and does not introduce new backend endpoints or break current navigation from the Suppliers page to /store/$supplierId.

Redesign the Home page (frontend/src/pages/HomePage.tsx) to closely match the layout, spacing, and visual hierarchy shown in the 3 uploaded screenshots, including: a minimal top bar (logo left, a single right-aligned CTA link/button), a hero section with headline + supporting text + email input + primary CTA button and a hero illustration, a horizontal “trusted by” logo row, a dark feature section with a large heading and 2–3 feature cards, a light stats section with two large stat cards, a “Build with help by your side” 2x2 icon/text grid, a dark FAQ section using an accordion list, and a bottom email CTA section above the footer. Use English for all user-facing text.

Update the app shell so the landing page is publicly viewable without requiring Internet Identity login, while keeping all other pages protected as they are today. Specifically: unauthenticated users visiting the home route (/) should see the redesigned landing page instead of the authentication-gated screen; unauthenticated users visiting other routes should still be prompted to log in.

Add a landing-page-only header/footer presentation that matches the screenshots (minimal header with logo + a single right-side CTA, and a simple footer link row), without breaking the existing in-app Header/Footer used for authenticated users.

Remove all visible references to the brand name “Shopify” from the public landing page and replace them with “Shanju”, ensuring all user-facing text remains in English and reads naturally (no trademarked phrasing).
Update the landing-page-only header branding to use the “Shanju” name (e.g., logo alt text and any visible brand label if present) without changing authentication-gated header behavior.

Replace the landing page’s current placeholder/fake marketing images with new, visually coherent, non-branded images selected by the developer, implemented as static assets under frontend/public/assets/generated and referenced via frontend/src/utils/assets.ts.

Update the landing page email capture (“Start free trial”) so it no longer behaves as UI-only; instead it must start a real onboarding flow that uses Internet Identity login (not email magic links) and then routes the user into the authenticated app.
Persist the email address entered on the landing page across the Internet Identity login redirect and use it to prefill the profile creation UI when the ProfileSetupModal is shown.
Fix onboarding/brand copy in the profile creation modal so it matches the app’s current brand and does not reference unrelated branding.
Update the landing-page header CTA so it meaningfully supports onboarding (rather than linking back to /) and does not mislead users into expecting an email-based login.

When a user is authenticated (Internet Identity is present) and visits the home route (/), automatically redirect them to the seller dashboard route (/seller-dashboard) so the public landing page never renders for authenticated users.

Ensure the existing onboarding redirect logic (onboardingStorage redirect target set by the landing page 'Start free trial') continues to work, and that it does not conflict with the new authenticated / -> /seller-dashboard redirect (i.e., onboarding redirect should still take precedence when present).

Redesign the Seller Dashboard page UI (frontend/src/pages/SellerDashboardPage.tsx) to closely match the layout, spacing, and visual hierarchy of the two uploaded Shopify admin mobile screenshots, while allowing small visual differences and keeping all user-facing text in English.

Implement a Shopify-admin-like top header section within the Seller Dashboard content (not the global app Header) that matches the screenshots: a dark bar with a menu icon, a prominent search input, a notifications icon, and a circular user/store badge placeholder. This header must not change global navigation behavior outside the dashboard.

Update the Seller Dashboard main content to follow the screenshot’s onboarding/checklist card pattern (e.g., ‘Add store name’, ‘Add your first product’, and additional setup cards), wiring CTAs to existing app actions: store name/settings must navigate to /create-store, and ‘Add product’ must open the existing ProductFormDialog. Any additional setup cards may be informational-only if no corresponding feature exists, but must look consistent and not break navigation.
Ensure the Seller Dashboard contains no visible occurrences of the brand name ‘Shopify’; replace any such visible copy with ‘Shanju’ where branding is needed. Keep all user-facing text in English.

Refine the Seller Dashboard page layout and styling (frontend/src/pages/SellerDashboardPage.tsx and its seller dashboard components) so the overall structure, spacing, and visual hierarchy more closely match the provided Shopify-admin mobile screenshots; treat the current implementation as a first draft and adjust until the page reads as the same layout at mobile widths.

Update the dashboard-only top bar (frontend/src/components/seller/SellerDashboardTopBar.tsx) to better match the screenshot styling by tuning its height, padding, icon sizing, search field appearance, and alignment for mobile-first presentation while keeping it within dashboard content (not modifying the global Header).

Make the seller product management section mobile-appropriate by rendering products in a responsive layout: keep the existing table layout for larger screens, but on small screens render a stacked card/list presentation that matches the mobile admin feel while preserving all current actions (edit, delete, quick stock update) and existing empty/loading states.
Investigate the current build/deployment failure, identify the root cause, and implement the minimal code/configuration changes required so the project builds and deploys successfully again.

Update the Seller Dashboard top bar UI (frontend/src/components/seller/SellerDashboardTopBar.tsx) to visually match the uploaded screenshot more closely on mobile, including: (1) a prominent circular hamburger/menu button on the left, (2) a dark rounded search field with appropriate padding/icon alignment, and (3) right-side icons sized/aligned to match the screenshot’s visual hierarchy.

Implement a dashboard-only left slide-out navigation drawer opened by the top-bar hamburger/menu button, matching the screenshot’s pattern (light drawer surface, icon + label rows). The drawer must include English navigation entries that map to existing app routes/features where possible: Home (Seller Dashboard), Products (scroll to product list section or keep focus on the products area), Orders (informational placeholder), Customers (informational placeholder), Marketing (informational placeholder), Discounts (informational placeholder), Content (informational placeholder), Markets (informational placeholder), Analytics (informational placeholder), Online Store (navigate to the existing public store view for the current supplier), Settings (navigate to /create-store).

Add a three-dot (overflow) menu in the Seller Dashboard top bar that opens a small actions menu aligned to the screenshot’s “more options” expectation. Include at least: Store Settings (navigate to /create-store), View Store (navigate to /store/$supplierId), and Logout (trigger existing Internet Identity logout flow).

Update the seller dashboard gating so it does not incorrectly show the 'Create Your Store First' prompt during transient loading/error states; it should only show the create-store prompt when the caller supplier profile query has definitively resolved to null.

Prevent the authenticated global app Header/Footer from visually colliding with the Seller Dashboard’s internal (dashboard-only) top bar on mobile. The Seller Dashboard route (/seller-dashboard) must render in a layout where the dashboard top bar is the primary top navigation element, without double-stacked headers causing cramped or overlapping UI.

Fix stacking (z-index) and positioning so the Seller Dashboard left navigation drawer and its overlay always appear above dashboard content and the sticky dashboard top bar, with correct layering and no bleed-through or mixed UI elements.

Fix the Seller Dashboard overflow (three-dot) menu rendering on mobile so it opens in the correct place relative to the top bar and does not overlap/jumble with the onboarding header text (“Good morning, let's get started.”) or other content due to incorrect positioning/layering.

Make the Seller Dashboard onboarding/setup cards fully responsive on small screens so internal button rows and card content never overflow, collide, or overlap. In particular, ensure the “Store Settings” and “View Store” actions in the first onboarding card wrap/stack appropriately on narrow widths.

Update the Seller Dashboard three-dot (overflow) menu dropdown so the menu options render on a white background with appropriate contrast (readable text/icons) and a subtle border/shadow, without changing the menu items, routes, or logout behavior.

new_feature_requests.summary: Redesign the site to be Shopify-like (full Shopify-style UI/UX and theme across pages)
Enable anyone to create an online store on the platform (multi-store/multi-seller store creation flow)
Add Product and Add Store sections with role-based access control (initially requested: only dropshippers can access)
Seller/Dropshipper dashboard for managing store and products
Storefront pages that visitors can browse (product listings, product details, etc.)
Checkout flow similar to Shopify (e.g., Stripe integration)

Add backend endpoints needed to support seller dashboard ergonomics without requiring the frontend to pass principals manually (e.g., getCallerSupplierProfile and getCallerSupplierProducts) and wire them into new React Query hooks.
Add product photo upload/management for products (attach images to product listings)
Add product inventory management (stock quantity tracking/updates)
Add product category list and category assignment/browsing for products
Add a Store View page/section (view store storefront/preview store)
Recreate a Shopify store landing page to match the provided screenshot design (same layout/UI)
Rebrand landing page copy to remove all 'Shopify' references and use 'Shanju' instead; replace fake/placeholder images with suitable real images

Implement functional 'Start free trial' onboarding: capture email and either (a) send a login method (magic link/OTP/password) or (b) redirect appropriately to an authenticated dashboard flow so users can actually enter the dashboard after starting a trial.

After a user completes the first 'free trial' login/onboarding, do not show the landing page again for that user; on future visits route them directly to the authenticated dashboard (e.g., /dashboard) instead of showing the landing page.

Redesign the Seller Dashboard UI to closely match the provided Shopify-style screenshot, allowing slight layout changes, and replace any 'Shopify' naming with 'Shanju' branding throughout the dashboard

Persist supplier store profiles (and the user-to-supplier association) in stable canister state so that after a user has created a store once, logging in again continues to return the existing supplier profile instead of appearing as missing.

projectName: Redesign app to feel Shopify-like and add self-serve store creation + seller dashboard
